article_title: Sustaining the Mountain Pass Mine in California

passage_list.text: Before we get into our material future, it’s important to point out just how hard it’s always been to make accurate predictions of this kind. Just look at our continuous theorizing about the supply of fossil fuels. One version of the story, told frequently in economics classes, goes something like this: Given that there’s a limited supply of oil, at some point the world will run out of it. Before then, we should reach some maximum amount of oil extraction, and then production will start an irreversible decline. That high point is known as “peak oil.”

This idea has been traced back as far as the early 1900s, but one of the most famous analyses came from M. King Hubbert, who was a geologist at Shell. In a 1956 paper, Hubbert considered the total amount of oil (and other fossil fuels, like coal and natural gas) that geologists had identified on the planet. From the estimated supply and the amount the world had burned through, he predicted that oil production in the US would peak and begin declining between 1965 and 1970. The peak of world oil production, he predicted, would come a bit later, in 2000.

For a while, it looked as if Hubbert was right. US oil production increased until 1970, when it reached a dramatic peak. It then declined for decades afterward, until about 2010. But then advances in drilling and fracking techniques unlocked hardto- reach reserves. Oil production skyrocketed in the US through the 2010s, and as of 2023, the country was producing more oil than ever before. Peak-oil panic has long outlived Hubbert, but every time economists and geologists have predicted that we’ve reached, or are about to reach, the peak of oil production, they’ve missed the mark (so far).

Now there’s a new reason we might see fossil-fuel production actually peak and eventually fall off: the energy transition. That’s shorthand for the grand effort to shift away from energy sources that produce greenhouse gases and toward renewables and other low-carbon options. Hubbert’s theory suggested that a fixed supply would force production to decline from a peak. But as the world wakes up to the dangers of climate change, and as low-carbon energy sources like wind, solar, and nuclear take off, we may wind up leaving some coal, oil, and natural gas in the ground. Simply put, production might head back down because of a lack of demand, not a lack of supply.

Those newly ascendant energy sources, though, are ironically a new source of “peak” panic. Solar panels, wind turbines, and batteries may not require fuel, but they do require a host of metals, including lithium, copper, steel, and rare earths like neodymium.

If we extract, process, use, and discard these metals, conceptually there must be some point in the future when we run out of them. And as the energy transition has gotten underway, plenty of forecasts have attempted to understand which metals we should worry about and when they might start to be depleted. But experts say that understanding the availability of resources in this sector is much more complicated than picking out a single future peak. “The peak modeling thing is something that doesn’t really apply to metals,” says Simon Jowitt, director of the Center for Research in Economic Geology at the University of Nevada, Reno. It’s nearly impossible to understand whether we’ve reached a peak in production for any given material, or even whether those peaks can be predicted, as Jowitt said in a 2020 paper.

Let’s take a closer look at neodymium. Reserves of the metal—the amount we know about that’s economically feasible to extract—have been estimated at 12.8 million tons. To keep the world from warming more than 1.5 °C over preindustrial levels, we might need as much as 121,000 tons every year just for wind turbines, according to a 2023 study on the material demands of the energy transition. Depending on how much material we assume makes it from the mine into final products, we could burn through those reserves in roughly a century. The problem with this thinking, though, is that reserves and resources are far from fixed. Geologists discover new deposits all the time, for one thing. And what was considered too expensive and difficult to mine a few decades ago might be possible to extract with today’s technology. So instead of being slowly depleted, those material supplies have roughly kept up with production.

“We are currently producing more metals than ever before and have more metal resources and reserves than ever before,” as Jowitt put it in his paper. And the question, he says, isn’t whether we’ll blow through what’s theoretically available on the planet, or even whether we’ll soon run out of material we can access and mine. It’s whether we’re willing to accept the social, ecological, and geopolitical consequences of how we mine today, and whether we might be able to change those for the better. Because we may be mining a lot more of some materials in the near future.

questions.question: The main idea of the passage is that

options.B: Predictions about resource supplies are often inaccurate

questions.explanation: The passage emphasizes the difficulty in making accurate predictions about resource supplies, using fossil fuels as an example to introduce the concept of peak oil.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Focus on the opening sentences to identify the overarching theme, rather than getting lost in specific examples.

questions.question: According to the passage, Hubbert's 1956 paper primarily focused on

options.B: Estimating total fossil fuel supplies and predicting production peaks

questions.explanation: Hubbert analyzed identified supplies of oil and other fuels, subtracting what had been used to predict US and world production peaks.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Scan for key details like predictions and methods described in the text to grasp the core content.

questions.question: It can reasonably be inferred from the passage that advances in fracking

options.B: Led to a reversal in the decline of US oil production
options.C: Caused peak oil to occur earlier than predicted
options.D: Reduced the need for fossil fuels

questions.explanation: The passage states that fracking unlocked hard-to-reach reserves, causing US oil production to skyrocket after a decades-long decline.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Connect cause-and-effect relationships in the text to draw logical conclusions beyond explicit statements.

questions.question: The second paragraph primarily serves to

options.A: Contrast supply-driven decline with demand-driven decline in fossil fuel production
options.B: Describe the history of fracking techniques
options.C: List examples of low-carbon energy sources

questions.explanation: It introduces the energy transition as a new reason for peaking due to lack of demand, differing from Hubbert's supply-based theory.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Examine how paragraphs build on or contrast previous ideas to understand their rhetorical role.

questions.question: As used in the passage, "peak modeling" most nearly means

options.A: Creating physical models of resource peaks
options.B: Forecasting maximum levels of production or extraction
options.C: Analyzing the shape of mountain ranges for mining

questions.explanation: The term refers to the approach of predicting a high point in production followed by decline, as applied to oil but questioned for metals.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use surrounding context about predictions and fossil fuels to determine the meaning of technical phrases.

questions.question: The passage implies that the energy transition could lead to a decline in fossil fuel production primarily because

options.A: Supplies will be exhausted faster due to increased demand
options.B: Technological advances will make extraction uneconomical
options.C: Renewable alternatives will reduce the need for fossil fuels, leaving reserves untapped
options.D: Geopolitical factors will restrict access to reserves

questions.explanation: The author contrasts Hubbert's supply-limited peak with a demand-driven one from the shift to renewables, potentially leaving fuels in the ground.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Synthesize ideas across sentences to infer broader implications, especially contrasts between theories.

questions.question: The author includes the quotation from Simon Jowitt primarily to

options.A: Support the idea that metals will peak similarly to oil
options.B: Illustrate why traditional peak predictions are inadequate for metals
options.C: Provide evidence for increasing demand in the energy transition
options.D: Emphasize the role of geologists in forecasting

questions.explanation: Jowitt's quote directly challenges the applicability of peak modeling to metals, aligning with the passage's argument on resource complexity.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Analyze how quotes function rhetorically to advance the author's argument or counter common assumptions.

questions.question: Which choice provides the best evidence for the claim that neodymium reserves might not be depleted as quickly as initial calculations suggest?

options.A: Reserves have been estimated at 12.8 million tons
options.B: Geologists discover new deposits all the time, and technology advances make extraction feasible
options.C: We might need 121,000 tons every year for wind turbines
options.D: A 2023 study discusses material demands of the energy transition

questions.explanation: This sentence explains why reserves are not fixed, countering the century-long depletion estimate by highlighting discoveries and technological improvements.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Link evidence directly to claims by identifying sentences that explain or qualify numerical projections.

questions.question: The phrase "The problem with this thinking, though," at the beginning of the last sentence most directly suggests a transition to

options.A: Agreeing with the century-long depletion estimate
options.B: Challenging the assumption of fixed reserves

questions.explanation: It signals a contrast to the preceding depletion calculation, emphasizing that reserves change due to discoveries and technology.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Pay attention to transitional phrases that indicate contrast or qualification to understand shifts in argumentative flow.

questions.question: The final passage connects most directly to earlier discussions in the article by shifting the focus from

options.A: Fossil fuel predictions to metal production increases
options.B: Concerns about running out of resources to the consequences of current mining practices
options.C: Historical analyses to future geopolitical risks

questions.explanation: It reframes the debate away from depletion fears (raised earlier with oil and metals) toward social, ecological, and geopolitical issues of mining.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Trace how concluding sections synthesize or pivot from prior themes to identify overarching connections.

scoring_guidelines.800_level_performance: Students scoring at this level demonstrate mastery of all tested skills, including advanced analysis, synthesis, and reasoning across complex texts.
scoring_guidelines.700_level_performance: Students scoring at this level show strong comprehension and reasoning skills but may struggle with higher-level inferences and rhetorical analysis.

explanation_summary.hard_questions: Hard questions test advanced analytical and reasoning skills, often requiring students to infer implications, evaluate evidence, or analyze rhetorical purposes.
explanation_summary.medium_questions: Medium questions assess comprehension and vocabulary in context, with a focus on understanding inferences and structural elements.
explanation_summary.easy_questions: Easy questions evaluate basic comprehension and the ability to identify explicit central ideas and details in the text.
